    Activation functions #

    ðŸ‘‰ Check Comparison of activation functions on wikipedia.

    Why non-linear activation functions in NN Model? #

    Suppose g(z)=zg(z)=zg(z)=z (linear)

    a[1]=g(z[1]=z[1])=w[1]x+b[1](linear)a[1]=g(z[2]=z[2])=w[2]a[1]+b[2]=(w[2]w[1])x+(w[2]b[1]+b[2])(linearÂ again).\begin{aligned} a^{[1]} &= g(z^{[1]} = z^{[1]}) = w^{[1]}x + b^{[1]} \quad \text{(linear)} \\ a^{[1]} &= g(z^{[2]} = z^{[2]}) = w^{[2]}a^{[1]} + b^{[2]} \\ &= (w^{[2]}w^{[1]})x + (w^{[2]}b^{[1]} + b^{[2]}) \quad \text{(linear again)}. \end{aligned}a[1]a[1]â€‹=g(z[1]=z[1])=w[1]x+b[1](linear)=g(z[2]=z[2])=w[2]a[1]+b[2]=(w[2]w[1])x+(w[2]b[1]+b[2])(linearÂ again).â€‹

    You might not have any hidden layer! Your model is just Logistic Regression, no hidden unit! Just use non-linear activations for hidden layers!

    Sigmoid function #

    • Usually used in the output layer in the binary classification.
    • Don't use sigmoid in the hidden layers!
    Ïƒ(z)=11+eâˆ’zÏƒ(z)â†’zâ†’âˆž1Ïƒ(z)â†’zâ†’âˆ’âˆž0Ïƒâ€²(x)=Ïƒ(x)(1âˆ’Ïƒ(x))\begin{aligned} \sigma(z) &= \dfrac{1}{1+e^{-z}} \\ \sigma(z) &\xrightarrow{z\to \infty} 1 \\ \sigma(z) &\xrightarrow{z\to -\infty} 0 \\ \sigma'(x) &= \sigma(x) (1 - \sigma(x)) \end{aligned}Ïƒ(z)Ïƒ(z)Ïƒ(z)Ïƒâ€²(x)â€‹=1+eâˆ’z1â€‹zâ†’âˆžâ€‹1zâ†’âˆ’âˆžâ€‹0=Ïƒ(x)(1âˆ’Ïƒ(x))â€‹


    Signmoid function graph on Wikipedia.

    import numpy as np
    import numpy as np

    def sigmoid(z):
        return 1 / (1+np.exp(-z))
    def sigmoid_derivative(z):
        return sigmoid(z)*(1-sigmoid(z))

    Softmax function #

    The output of the softmax function can be used to represent a categorical distribution â€“ that is, a probability distribution over K different possible outcomes.


    Udacity Deep Learning Slide on Softmax

    Ïƒ(z)i=eziâˆ‘j=1KezjÂ forÂ i=1,â€¦,KÂ andÂ zâˆˆRK\sigma (\mathbf {z} )_{i}={\frac {e^{z_{i}}}{\sum _{j=1}^{K}e^{z_{j}}}}{\text{ for }}i=1,\dotsc ,K{\text{ and }}\mathbf {z}\in \mathbb {R} ^{K}Ïƒ(z)iâ€‹=âˆ‘j=1Kâ€‹ezjâ€‹eziâ€‹â€‹Â forÂ i=1,â€¦,KÂ andÂ zâˆˆRK
    def softmax(x):
        z_exp = np.exp(z)
        z_sum = np.sum(z_exp, axis=1, keepdims=True)
        return z_exp / z_sum

    tanh function (Hyperbolic tangent) #

    • tanh is better than sigmoid because mean â†’\toâ†’ 0 and it centers the data better for the next layer.
    • Don't use sigmoid on hidden units except for the output layer because in the case 0â‰¤y^â‰¤10 \le \hat{y} \le 10â‰¤y^â€‹â‰¤1, sigmoid is better than tanh.
    Ïƒ(z)=ezâˆ’eâˆ’zez+eâˆ’z\sigma(z) = \dfrac{e^{z} - e^{-z}}{e^{z} + e^{-z}}Ïƒ(z)=ez+eâˆ’zezâˆ’eâˆ’zâ€‹
    def tanh(z):
        return (np.exp(z) - np.exp(-z)) / (np.exp(z) + np.exp(-z))


    Graph of tanh from analyticsindiamag.

    ReLU #

    • ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit).
    • Its derivative is much different from 0 than sigmoid/tanh â†’\toâ†’ learn faster!
    • If you aren't sure which one to use in the activation, use ReLU!
    • Weakness: derivative ~ 0 in the negative side, we use Leaky ReLU instead! However, Leaky ReLU aren't used much in practice!
    Ïƒ(z)=maxâ¡(0,z)\sigma(z) = \max(0,z)Ïƒ(z)=max(0,z)
    def relu(z):
        return np.maximum(0, z)


    ReLU (left) and Leaky ReLU (right)

    Logistic Regression #

    • Usually used for binary classification (there are only 2 outputs). In the case of multiclass classification, we can use one vs all (couple multiple logistic regression steps).

    Gradient Descent #

    Gradient Descent is an algorithm to minimizing the cose function JJJ. It contains 2 steps: Forward Propagation (From XXX to compute the cost JJJ) and Backward Propagation (compute derivaties and optimize the parameters w,bw, bw,b).

    Initialize w,bw, bw,b and then repeat until convergence (mmm: number of training examples, Î±\alphaÎ±: learning rate, JJJ: cost function, AAA: activation function):

    1. A=Ïƒ(wTX+b)A = \sigma(w^TX + b)A=Ïƒ(wTX+b)
    2. J(w,b)=âˆ’1m(Ylogâ¡AT+(1âˆ’Y)logâ¡(1âˆ’AT))J(w,b) = -\frac{1}{m} \left( Y \log A^T + (1-Y)\log(1-A^T) \right)J(w,b)=âˆ’m1â€‹(YlogAT+(1âˆ’Y)log(1âˆ’AT))
    3. âˆ‚wJ=1mX(Aâˆ’Y)T\partial_{w}J = \frac{1}{m}X(A-Y)^Tâˆ‚wâ€‹J=m1â€‹X(Aâˆ’Y)T
    4. âˆ‚bJ=1mÎ£(Aâˆ’Y)\partial_{b}J = \frac{1}{m} \Sigma (A-Y)âˆ‚bâ€‹J=m1â€‹Î£(Aâˆ’Y)
    5. w:=wâˆ’Î±âˆ‚wJw := w - \alpha \partial_{w}Jw:=wâˆ’Î±âˆ‚wâ€‹J
    6. b:=bâˆ’Î±âˆ‚bJb := b - \alpha \partial_{b}Jb:=bâˆ’Î±âˆ‚bâ€‹J

    The dimension of variables: XâˆˆRnxÃ—m,YâˆˆR1Ã—m,bâˆˆR1Ã—m,wâˆˆRnxÃ—1,AâˆˆR1Ã—m,JâˆˆRX\in \mathbb{R}^{n_x \times m}, Y\in \mathbb{R}^{1\times m}, b\in \mathbb{R}^{1\times m}, w\in \mathbb{R}^{n_x \times 1}, A\in \mathbb{R}^{1\times m}, J\in \mathbb{R}XâˆˆRnxâ€‹Ã—m,YâˆˆR1Ã—m,bâˆˆR1Ã—m,wâˆˆRnxâ€‹Ã—1,AâˆˆR1Ã—m,JâˆˆR, âˆ‚wJâˆˆR\partial_wJ \in \mathbb{R}âˆ‚wâ€‹JâˆˆR, âˆ‚bJâˆˆR\partial_bJ \in \mathbb{R}âˆ‚bâ€‹JâˆˆR.

    Code #

    def logistic_regression_model(X_train, Y_train, X_test, Y_test,
                                  num_iterations = 2000, learning_rate = 0.5):
        m = X_train.shape[1] # number of training examples

        # INITIALIZE w, b
        w = np.zeros((X_train.shape[0], 1))
        b = 0

        # GRADIENT DESCENT
        for i in range(num_iterations):
            # FORWARD PROPAGATION (from x to cost)
            A = sigmoid(np.dot(w.T, X_train) + b)
            cost = -1/m * (np.dot(Y, np.log(A.T))
                   + p.dot((1-Y), np.log(1-A.T)))

            # BACKWARD PROPAGATION (find grad)
            dw = 1/m * np.dot(X_train, (A-Y).T)
            db = 1/m * np.sum(A-Y)
            cost = np.squeeze(cost)

            # OPTIMIZE
            w = w - learning_rate*dw
            b = b - learning_rate*db

        # PREDICT (with optimized w, b)
        Y_pred = np.zeros((1,m))
        w = w.reshape(X.shape[0], 1)

        A = sigmoid(np.dot(w.T,X_test) + b)
        Y_pred_test = A > 0.5

    Neural Network overview #

    Notations #

    • X(i)X^{(i)}X(i) : iiith training example.
    • mmm : number of examples.
    • LLL : number of layers.
    • n[0]=nXn^{[0]} = n_Xn[0]=nXâ€‹ : number of features (# nodes in the input).
    • n[L]n^{[L]}n[L] : number of nodes in the output layer.
    • n[l]n^{[l]}n[l] : number of nodes in the hidden layers.
    • w[l]w^{[l]}w[l] : weights for z[l]z^{[l]}z[l].
    • a[0]=Xa^{[0]} = Xa[0]=X : activation in the input layer.
    • ai[2]a^{[2]}_iai[2]â€‹ : activation in layer 222, node iii.
    • a[2](i)a^{[2](i)}a[2](i) : activation in layer 222, example iii.
    • a[L]=y^a^{[L]} = \hat{y}a[L]=y^â€‹.

    Dimensions #

    • A[0]=XâˆˆRn[0]Ã—mA^{[0]} = X \in \mathbb{R}^{n^{[0]} \times m}A[0]=XâˆˆRn[0]Ã—m
    • Z[l],A[l]âˆˆRn[l]Ã—mZ^{[l]}, A^{[l]} \in \mathbb{R}^{n^{[l]}\times m}Z[l],A[l]âˆˆRn[l]Ã—m.
    • dZ[l],dA[l]âˆˆRn[l]Ã—mdZ^{[l]}, dA^{[l]} \in \mathbb{R}^{n^{[l]}\times m}dZ[l],dA[l]âˆˆRn[l]Ã—m.
    • dW[l],W[l]âˆˆRn[l]Ã—[lâˆ’1]dW^{[l]}, W^{[l]} \in \mathbb{R}^{n^{[l]} \times ^{[l-1]}}dW[l],W[l]âˆˆRn[l]Ã—[lâˆ’1].
    • db[l],b[l]âˆˆRn[l]Ã—1db^{[l]}, b^{[l]} \in \mathbb{R}^{n^{[l]} \times 1}db[l],b[l]âˆˆRn[l]Ã—1.

    L-layer deep neural network #


    L-layer deep neural network. Image from the course.

    1. Initialize parameters / Define hyperparameters
    2. Loop for num_iterations:
      1. Forward propagation
      2. Compute cost function
      3. Backward propagation
      4. Update parameters (using parameters, and grads from backprop)
    3. Use trained parameters to predict labels.

    Initialize parameters #

    • In the Logistic Regression, we use 000 for w,bw, bw,b (it's OK because LogR doesn't have hidden layers) but we can't in the NN model!
    • If we use 000, we'll meet the completely symmetric problem. No matter how long you train your NN, hidden units compute exactly the same function â‡’\Rightarrowâ‡’ No point to having more than 1 hidden unit!
    • We add a little bit in WWW and keep 000 in bbb.

    Forward & Backward Propagation #


    Blocks of forward and backward propagation deep NN. Unknown source.


    Blocks of forward and backward propagation deep NN. Image from the course.

    Forward Propagation: Loop through number of layers:

    1. A[0]=XA^{[0]} = XA[0]=X
    2. Z[l]=W[l]A[lâˆ’1]+b[l]Z^{[l]} = W^{[l]}A^{[l-1]} + b^{[l]}Z[l]=W[l]A[lâˆ’1]+b[l] (linear)
    3. A[l]=Ïƒ[l](Z[l])A^{[l]} = \sigma^{[l]}(Z^{[l]})A[l]=Ïƒ[l](Z[l]) (for l=1â€¦Lâˆ’1l=1 \ldots L-1l=1â€¦Lâˆ’1, non-linear activations)
    4. A[L]=Ïƒ[L](Z[L])A^{[L]} = \sigma^{[L]}(Z^{[L]})A[L]=Ïƒ[L](Z[L]) (sigmoid function)

    Cost function: J(w,b)=âˆ’1m(Ylogâ¡AT+(1âˆ’Y)logâ¡(1âˆ’AT))J(w,b) = -\frac{1}{m} \left( Y \log A^T + (1-Y)\log(1-A^T) \right)J(w,b)=âˆ’m1â€‹(YlogAT+(1âˆ’Y)log(1âˆ’AT))

    Backward Propagation: Loop through number of layers

    1. dA[L]=âˆ’yA[L]+1âˆ’y1âˆ’A[L]dA^{[L]} = -\frac{y}{A^{[L]}} + \frac{1-y}{1-A^{[L]}}dA[L]=âˆ’A[L]yâ€‹+1âˆ’A[L]1âˆ’yâ€‹.
    2. for l=Lâ€¦1l=L \ldots 1l=Lâ€¦1, non-linear activations:
      1. dZ[l]=dA[l](Ïƒ[l])â€²(Z[l])dZ^{[l]} = dA^{[l]} (\sigma^{[l]})'(Z^{[l]})dZ[l]=dA[l](Ïƒ[l])â€²(Z[l]).
      2. dW[l]=dJâˆ‚W[l]=1mdZ[l](A[lâˆ’1])TdW^{[l]} = \frac{dJ}{\partial W^{[l]}} = \frac{1}{m} dZ^{[l]} (A^{[l-1])^T}dW[l]=âˆ‚W[l]dJâ€‹=m1â€‹dZ[l](A[lâˆ’1])T.
      3. db[l]=dJâˆ‚b[l]=1mÏƒ1mdZ[l](i)db^{[l]} = \frac{dJ}{\partial b^{[l]}} = \frac{1}{m}\sigma_1^m dZ^{[l](i)}db[l]=âˆ‚b[l]dJâ€‹=m1â€‹Ïƒ1mâ€‹dZ[l](i).
      4. dA[lâˆ’1]=(W[l])TdZ[l]dA^{[l-1]} = (W^{[l])^T}dZ^{[l]}dA[lâˆ’1]=(W[l])TdZ[l].

    Update parameters: loop through number of layers (for l=1â€¦Ll=1\ldots Ll=1â€¦L)

    1. W[l]=W[l]âˆ’Î±dW[l]W^{[l]} = W^{[l]} - \alpha dW^{[l]}W[l]=W[l]âˆ’Î±dW[l].
    2. b[l]=b[l]âˆ’Î±db[l]b^{[l]} = b^{[l]} - \alpha db^{[l]}b[l]=b[l]âˆ’Î±db[l].

    Code #

    def L_Layer_NN(X, Y, layers_dims, learning_rate=0.0075,
                   num_iterations=3000, print_cost=False):
        costs = []
        m = X_train.shape[1] # number of training examples
        L = len(layer_dims)  # number of layers

        # INITIALIZE W, b
        params = {'W':[], 'b':[]}
        for l in range(L):
            params['W'][l] = np.random.randn(layer_dims[l], layer_dims[l-1]) * 0.01
            params['b'][l] = np.zeros((layer_dims[l], 1))

        # GRADIENT DESCENT
        for i in range(0, num_iterations):
            # FORWARD PROPAGATION (Linear -> ReLU x (L-1) -> Linear -> Sigmoid (L))
            A = X
            caches = {'A':[], 'W':[], 'b':[], 'Z':[]}
            for l in range(L):
                caches['A_prev'].append(A)
                # INITIALIZE W, b
                W = params['W'][l]
                b = params['b'][l]
                caches['W'].append(W)
                caches['b'].append(b)
                # RELU X (L-1)
                Z = np.dot(W, A) + b
                if l != L: # hidden layers
                    A = relu(Z)
                else: # output layer
                    A = sigmoid(Z)
                caches['Z'].append(Z)

            # COST
            cost = -1/m * np.dot(np.log(A), Y.T) - 1/m * np.dot(np.log(1-A), 1-Y.T)

            #FORWARD PROPAGATION (Linear -> ReLU x (L-1) -> Linear -> Sigmoid (L))
            dA = - (np.divide(Y, A) - np.divide(1 - Y, 1 - A))
            grads = {'dW':[], 'db':[]}
            for l in reversed(range(L)):
                cache_Z = caches['Z'][l]
                if l != L-1: # hidden layers
                    dZ = np.array(dA, copy=True)
                    dZ[Z <= 0] = 0
                else: # output layer
                    dZ = dA * sigmoid(cache_Z)*(1-sigmoid(cache_Z))
                cache_A_prev = caches['A_prev'][l]
                dW = 1/m * np.dot(dZ, cache_A_prev.T)
                db = 1/m * np.sum(dZ, axis=1, keepdims=True)
                dA = np.dot(W.T, dZ)
                grads['dW'].append(dW)
                grads['db'].append(db)

            # UPDATE PARAMETERS
            for l in range(L):
                params['W'][l+1] = params['W'][l] - grads['dW'][l]
                params['b'][l+1] = params['b'][l] - grads['db'][l]

        if print_cost and i % 100 == 0:
            print ("Cost after iteration %i: %f" %(i, cost))
        if print_cost and i % 100 == 0:
            costs.append(cost)

        return parameter

    Parameters vs Hyperparameters #

    • Parameters: W,bW, bW,b.
    • Hyperparameters:
      • Learning rate (Î±\alphaÎ±).
      • Number of iterations (in gradient descent algorithm) (num_iterations).
      • Number of layers (LLL).
      • Number of nodes in each layer (n[i]n^{[i]}n[i]).
      • Choice of activation functions (their form, not their values).

    Comments #

    • Always use vectorized if possible! Especially for number of examples!
    • We can't use vectorized for number of layers, we need for.
    • Sometimes, functions computed with Deep NN (more layers, fewer nodes in each layer) is better than Shallow (fewer layers, more nodes). E.g. function XOR.
    • Deeper layer in the network, more complex features to be determined!
    • Applied deep learning is a very empirical process! Best values depend much on data, algorithms, hyperparameters, CPU, GPU,...
    • Learning algorithm works sometimes from data, not from your thousands line of codes (surprise!!!)

    Application: recognize a cat #

    This section contains an idea, not a complete task!


    Image to vector conversion. Image from the course.


    L-layer deep neural network. Image from the course.

    Python tips #

    â—‹ Reshape quickly from (10,9,9,3) to (9*9*3,10):

    X = np.random.rand(10, 9, 9, 3)
    X = X.reshape(10,-1).T

    â—‹ Don't use loop, use vectorization!
